channel.title: Cell
channel.description: Cell RSS feed. For more than 30 years, top international researchers have relied on Cell to publish high impact papers that have come to form the foundation of contemporary life science research. Founded by Benjamin Lewin (author of Genes), Cell remains at the forefront of exciting developments in biology, continually redefining the important areas of science with cutting edge papers. Published biweekly, Cell includes original research articles of exceptional significance in areas including molecular biology, biochemistry, cancer research, cell biology, developmental biology, genetics, immunology, microbiology, neurobiology, plant biology, structural biology and virology. Submitted articles are reviewed rapidly for both technical quality and general interest, and, if accepted, are published within eight weeks. Cell features topical minireview and review articles in which noted scientists discuss current progress in all areas of the life sciences. Cell also publishes commentaries, meeting reviews, letters to the editor, and book reviews, as well as Positions Available and listings of Conferences and Courses.Visit the Cell website to find out more - http://www.cell.com.
channel.dc:rights: © 2015 Published by Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2015 Published by Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Broadly Neutralizing Alphavirus Antibodies Bind an Epitope on E2 and Inhibit Entry and Egress
item.description: A class of broadly neutralizing monoclonal antibodies identified here protects against infection and disease in vivo against multiple alphaviruses, including chikungunya. These antibodies bind a discrete epitope on the alphavirus E2 glycoprotein, block viral entry and egress, and allow cross-linking of adjacent E2 protein spikes, suggesting avenues for possible vaccine- or antibody-based therapeutic development against multiple alphaviruses.
item.dc:title: Broadly Neutralizing Alphavirus Antibodies Bind an Epitope on E2 and Inhibit Entry and Egress
item.dc:creator: Julie M. Fox, Feng Long, Melissa A. Edeling, Hueylie Lin, Mareike K.S. van Duijl-Richter, Rachel H. Fong, Kristen M. Kahle, Jolanda M. Smit, Jing Jin, Graham Simmons, Benjamin J. Doranz, James E. Crowe, Daved H. Fremont, Michael G. Rossmann, Michael S. Diamond

item.title: Molecular Mechanism of V(D)J Recombination from Synaptic RAG1-RAG2 Complex Structures
item.description: Cryo-EM structures of synaptic RAG complexes reveal a recombination signal sequence (RSS)-induced closed conformation that enables catalytic activation and explain the molecular basis for the 12/23 rule, a dogma in which 12-RSS and 23-RSS flanking the V, D, and J segments are synapsed.
item.dc:title: Molecular Mechanism of V(D)J Recombination from Synaptic RAG1-RAG2 Complex Structures
item.dc:creator: Heng Ru, Melissa G. Chambers, Tian-Min Fu, Alexander B. Tong, Maofu Liao, Hao Wu

item.title: MAJIN Links Telomeric DNA to the Nuclear Membrane by Exchanging Telomere Cap
item.description: During meiosis, telomeres experience a cap exchange process in which a protein complex localized at the inner nuclear membrane replaces the protective cap of chromosomes to ensure telomere tethering for correct chromosome recombination.
item.dc:title: MAJIN Links Telomeric DNA to the Nuclear Membrane by Exchanging Telomere Cap
item.dc:creator: Hiroki Shibuya, Abrahan Hernández-Hernández, Akihiro Morimoto, Lumi Negishi, Christer Höög, Yoshinori Watanabe

item.title: Relaxation of Loaded ESCRT-III Spiral Springs Drives Membrane Deformation
item.description: A component of the ESCRT-III membrane fission machinery self-organizes into spiral springs that trigger membrane deformation when released.
item.dc:title: Relaxation of Loaded ESCRT-III Spiral Springs Drives Membrane Deformation
item.dc:creator: Nicolas Chiaruttini, Lorena Redondo-Morata, Adai Colom, Frédéric Humbert, Martin Lenz, Simon Scheuring, Aurélien Roux

item.title: Surveillance and Processing of Foreign DNA by the CRISPR-Cas System
item.description: Single-molecule analysis of the bacterial Cascade complex reveals two distinct pathways leading to differential regulation of Cas3 DNA translocase and nuclease activities.
item.dc:title: Surveillance and Processing of Foreign DNA by the CRISPR-Cas System
item.dc:creator: Sy Redding, Samuel H. Sternberg, Myles Marshall, Bryan Gibb, Prashant Bhat, Chantal K. Guegler, Blake Wiedenheft, Jennifer A. Doudna, Eric C. Greene

item.title: Histone H3 Threonine Phosphorylation Regulates Asymmetric Histone Inheritance in the Male Germline
item.description: A transient mitosis-specific phosphate modification on histone H3 distinguishes pre-existing and newly synthesized histones and is required for the asymmetric segregation of sister chromatids—one enriched with new histones and the other with old—during stem cell division.
item.dc:title: Histone H3 Threonine Phosphorylation Regulates Asymmetric Histone Inheritance in the Male Germline
item.dc:creator: Jing Xie, Matthew Wooten, Vuong Tran, Bi-Chang Chen, Caitlin Pozmanter, Christine Simbolon, Eric Betzig, Xin Chen

item.title: Chromosomal Loop Domains Direct the Recombination of Antigen Receptor Genes
item.description: The 3D architecture of the genome harnesses RAG endonuclease activity by allowing it to directionally locate convergent recombination signal sequences and related CAC-containing motifs within individual chromatin loop domains.
item.dc:title: Chromosomal Loop Domains Direct the Recombination of Antigen Receptor Genes
item.dc:creator: Jiazhi Hu, Yu Zhang, Lijuan Zhao, Richard L. Frock, Zhou Du, Robin M. Meyers, Fei-long Meng, David G. Schatz, Frederick W. Alt

item.title: 5′ UTR mA Promotes Cap-Independent Translation
item.description: N6-methyladenosine (m6A) residues within the 5′ UTR of mRNAs promote translation initiation through a mechanism that does not require the 5′ cap or cap-binding proteins. Diverse cellular stresses selectively increase the levels of m6A within 5′ UTRs, suggesting that 5′ UTR m6A is important for mediating stress-induced translational responses.
item.dc:title: 5′ UTR mA Promotes Cap-Independent Translation
item.dc:creator: Kate D. Meyer, Deepak P. Patil, Jun Zhou, Alexandra Zinoviev, Maxim A. Skabkin, Olivier Elemento, Tatyana V. Pestova, Shu-Bing Qian, Samie R. Jaffrey

item.title: Structural and Mechanistic Basis of PAM-Dependent Spacer Acquisition in CRISPR-Cas Systems
item.description: Cas1 and Cas2 select an invading DNA sequence, termed protospacer, for insertion into the CRISPR locus of the host cell. The structure of the Cas1-Cas2-protospacer DNA complex reveals the dual-forked nature of the protospacer, explains how the protospacer is selected, and identifies how protospacer length is predetermined.
item.dc:title: Structural and Mechanistic Basis of PAM-Dependent Spacer Acquisition in CRISPR-Cas Systems
item.dc:creator: Jiuyu Wang, Jiazhi Li, Hongtu Zhao, Gang Sheng, Min Wang, Maolu Yin, Yanli Wang

item.title: Net Works for Malaria Control
item.description: In just a couple days, Youyou Tu, William C. Campbell and Satoshi Ōmura will meet His Majesty King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden to receive the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. Tu’s discovery of artemisinin, a potent anti-malarial. and Campbell and Ōmura’s work on ivermectin, a broad-spectrum antiparasitic drug, has helped to mitigate the burden of parasitic diseases, especially in the developing world. Despite all effort and advances, stopping the spread of preventable parasitic diseases remains an unmet goal.
item.dc:title: Net Works for Malaria Control

item.title: Peroxisomes Get Loud: A Redox Antidote to Hearing Loss
item.description: Pejvakin (PJVK), a protein originally identified in Persian families with sensorineural hearing loss, regulates peroxisomal dynamics and the antioxidant defense triggered by noise exposure in hair cells and auditory neurons of the inner ear. These findings bring peroxisomes to the forefront of noise-induced hearing loss research.
item.dc:title: Peroxisomes Get Loud: A Redox Antidote to Hearing Loss
item.dc:creator: Pablo Mardones, Claudio Hetz

item.title: In This Issue
item.description: WANG ET AL., PAGE 840
item.dc:title: In This Issue

item.title: Radical Sabbaticals
item.description: Growing up, I believed that academics were shielded from the clutter of everyday life and had the peace to think, discuss, perform the occasional experiment and think some more. After starting a research lab, however, I discovered there was not much peace in academia. The day was just not long enough to fit everything in, and though a sabbatical leave always lurked at the horizon, there never seemed to be a good moment to take a break.
item.dc:title: Radical Sabbaticals

item.title: Aire Gets Company for Immune Tolerance
item.description: A specialized subset of epithelial cells in the thymus “promiscuously” transcribes thousands of peripheral genes to ensure that developing T cells can test their antigen receptors for dangerous autoreactivity. New findings by Takaba et al. indicate that the transcription factor Fezf2 acts independently of Aire in thymic epithelial cells to generate “genetic noise” for immunological tolerance.
item.dc:title: Aire Gets Company for Immune Tolerance
item.dc:creator: Ludger Klein

item.title: Modifications on Translation Initiation
item.description: Two studies by Meyer et al. and Wang et al. demonstrate a role for m6A modification of mRNA in stimulating translation initiation. These findings add to the growing number of diverse mechanisms for translation initiation in eukaryotes.
item.dc:title: Modifications on Translation Initiation
item.dc:creator: Sarah F. Mitchell, Roy Parker

item.title: SnapShot: T Cell Exhaustion
item.description: Exhaustion is a state of T cell differentiation common during chronic infection and cancer that results in T cell dysfunction. Exhausted T cells (TEX) progressively lose effector functions and develop defects in memory T cell properties due to exposure to persistent antigen and inflammation. Exhaustion can be reversed, at least partially, by blocking inhibitory pathways such as PD-1, resulting in improved pathogen or tumor control. To view this SnapShot, open or download the PDF.
item.dc:title: SnapShot: T Cell Exhaustion
item.dc:creator: Kristen E. Pauken, E. John Wherry

item.title: A Gut Feeling about You
item.description: The “gut microbiota” is rapidly becoming a common term outside of the halls of science: it has been headlined in the New York Times, is the subject of several non-fiction books, and is regularly promoted on TV (probiotics, anyone…?). Many non-scientists may not remember or know the technical term microbiota, but mention the gut flora to them, and they’ll probably know what you’re referring to.
item.dc:title: A Gut Feeling about You
item.dc:creator: Corinne F. Maurice

item.title: Regulators of Gut Motility Revealed by a Gnotobiotic Model of Diet-Microbiome Interactions Related to Travel
item.dc:title: Regulators of Gut Motility Revealed by a Gnotobiotic Model of Diet-Microbiome Interactions Related to Travel
item.dc:creator: Neelendu Dey, Vitas E. Wagner, Laura V. Blanton, Jiye Cheng, Luigi Fontana, Rashidul Haque, Tahmeed Ahmed, Jeffrey I. Gordon

item.title: Adopting Rare Diseases
item.description: In the United States, rare diseases are defined as conditions affecting fewer than 200,000 individuals at any given time. Worldwide, an estimated 300 million people are affected by rare diseases, also known as “orphan diseases” because with few financial incentives for developing new treatments, the pharmaceutical industry did not “adopt” them. In his book entitled Orphan, Phillip Reilly paints a picture of several rare diseases and the quest to find treatments for them.
item.dc:title: Adopting Rare Diseases
item.dc:creator: Mustafa Sahin

item.title: Hippo Pathway in Organ Size Control, Tissue Homeostasis, and Cancer
item.description: In response to a variety of cellular signals, the Hippo pathway plays key roles in regulating tissue homeostasis, stemness, and cancer development.
item.dc:title: Hippo Pathway in Organ Size Control, Tissue Homeostasis, and Cancer
item.dc:creator: Fa-Xing Yu, Bin Zhao, Kun-Liang Guan

item.title: Histone Marks Direct Chromosome Segregation
item.description: Germline stem cells divide asymmetrically, producing a self-renewing stem cell and a differentiating progenitor. Xie et al. now show that this depends on two asymmetric events that together partition a genome copy, carrying the old histones to the stem cell daughter and a copy with new, unmarked histones to the differentiating daughter.
item.dc:title: Histone Marks Direct Chromosome Segregation
item.dc:creator: Vincenzo Pirrotta

item.title: The LC Domain of hnRNPA2 Adopts Similar Conformations in Hydrogel Polymers, Liquid-like Droplets, and Nuclei
item.description: A chemical footprinting method reveals that polymers of low-complexity domains exhibit similar cross-β structure in hydrogels, liquid-like droplets, and nuclei of mammalian cells, suggesting a common underlying structural basis.
item.dc:title: The LC Domain of hnRNPA2 Adopts Similar Conformations in Hydrogel Polymers, Liquid-like Droplets, and Nuclei
item.dc:creator: Siheng Xiang, Masato Kato, Leeju C. Wu, Yi Lin, Ming Ding, Yajie Zhang, Yonghao Yu, Steven L. McKnight

item.title: Design and Analysis of Single-Cell Sequencing Experiments
item.description: As the applications and accessibility of single-cell sequencing approaches expand, a number of tenets regarding experimental design and data analysis are important to keep in mind.
item.dc:title: Design and Analysis of Single-Cell Sequencing Experiments
item.dc:creator: Dominic Grün, Alexander van Oudenaarden

item.title: Cardiomyocytes Replicate and their Numbers Increase in Young Hearts
item.description: In mice, the heart nearly quadruples in size from early preadolescence (postnatal day 10 [P10]) to puberty (∼P35) (Naqvi et al., 2014). Because it is widely believed that mammalian cardiomyocytes (CMs) are incapable of replication after birth, it has been assumed that early postnatal heart growth is driven solely by CM hypertrophy. Our findings question this view and provide insights into how thyroid hormone may regulate an increase in CM number during preadolescence. Alkass et al. (2015) and Soonpaa et al.
item.dc:title: Cardiomyocytes Replicate and their Numbers Increase in Young Hearts
item.dc:creator: Nawazish Naqvi, Reena Singh, Siiri E. Iismaa, Ming Li, John W. Calvert, David I.K. Martin, Richard P. Harvey, Robert M. Graham, Ahsan Husain

item.title: Cardiomyocyte Cell-Cycle Activity during Preadolescence
item.description: Earlier studies (Soonpaa et al., 1996) revealed a rapid drop-off of ventricular cardiomyocyte cell-cycle activity at birth in mice, followed by a burst of DNA synthesis during the first week of postnatal life which contributed to the formation of multi-nucleated cardiomyocytes by postnatal day 10 (PN10). It has recently been suggested that a second burst of cardiomyocyte cell-cycle activity occurs during preadolescence, between PN14 and PN18, resulting in a 40% increase in cardiomyocyte number (Naqvi et al., 2014).
item.dc:title: Cardiomyocyte Cell-Cycle Activity during Preadolescence
item.dc:creator: Mark H. Soonpaa, David C. Zebrowski, Colin Platt, Anthony Rosenzweig, Felix B. Engel, Loren J. Field

item.title: No Evidence for Cardiomyocyte Number Expansion in Preadolescent Mice
item.description: Contrary to a recent report suggesting that a preadolescent burst of cardiomyocyte proliferation promotes heart growth, cardiomyocyte number expansion appears limited to the neonatal period, with cardiomyocyte hypertrophy likely accounting for the increase in the heart size.
item.dc:title: No Evidence for Cardiomyocyte Number Expansion in Preadolescent Mice
item.dc:creator: Kanar Alkass, Joni Panula, Mattias Westman, Ting-Di Wu, Jean-Luc Guerquin-Kern, Olaf Bergmann

item.title: Estrogen Receptor β Modulates Apoptosis Complexes and the Inflammasome to Drive the Pathogenesis of Endometriosis
item.description: Estrogen receptor β (ERβ) plays a unique role in endometriotic tissue, where it interacts with the cytoplasmic apoptotic machinery and inflammasome complex to prevent TNF-α-induced cell death and enhance adhesion and proliferative activities of endometriotic tissues. This non-genomic action of ERβ has a predominant role in endometriosis progression.
item.dc:title: Estrogen Receptor β Modulates Apoptosis Complexes and the Inflammasome to Drive the Pathogenesis of Endometriosis
item.dc:creator: Sang Jun Han, Sung Yun Jung, San-Pin Wu, Shannon M. Hawkins, Mi Jin Park, Satoru Kyo, Jun Qin, John P. Lydon, Sophia Y. Tsai, Ming-Jer Tsai, Francesco J. DeMayo, Bert W. O’Malley

item.title: Dissecting Polyclonal Vaccine-Induced Humoral Immunity against HIV Using Systems Serology
item.description: Systems Serology reveals unique vaccine-induced “fingerprints,” highlighting potential markers of protection against HIV and providing a powerful method for comparing candidate vaccines against pathogens for which correlates of protection remain elusive.
item.dc:title: Dissecting Polyclonal Vaccine-Induced Humoral Immunity against HIV Using Systems Serology
item.dc:creator: Amy W. Chung, Manu P. Kumar, Kelly B. Arnold, Wen Han Yu, Matthew K. Schoen, Laura J. Dunphy, Todd J. Suscovich, Nicole Frahm, Caitlyn Linde, Alison E. Mahan, Michelle Hoffner, Hendrik Streeck, Margaret E. Ackerman, M. Juliana McElrath, Hanneke Schuitemaker, Maria G. Pau, Lindsey R. Baden, Jerome H. Kim, Nelson L. Michael, Dan H. Barouch, Douglas A. Lauffenburger, Galit Alter

item.title: Stable Chromosome Condensation Revealed by Chromosome Conformation Capture
item.description: Analysis of polytene bands, which are shown to correspond to topologically associating domains in interphase nuclei, reveals two stable forms of folded chromatin within euchromatic regions of diploid cells that are distinct from more highly structured heterochromatin.
item.dc:title: Stable Chromosome Condensation Revealed by Chromosome Conformation Capture
item.dc:creator: Kyle P. Eagen, Tom A. Hartl, Roger D. Kornberg

item.title: The Molecular Taxonomy of Primary Prostate Cancer
item.description: Molecular analysis of 333 primary prostate carcinomas reveals substantial heterogeneity and major subtypes among patients, as well as potentially actionable lesions valuable for clinical management of the disease.
item.dc:title: The Molecular Taxonomy of Primary Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: The Cancer Genome Atlas Research Network

item.title: Hypervulnerability to Sound Exposure through Impaired Adaptive Proliferation of Peroxisomes
item.description: Hypervulnerability to sound exposure in pejvakin-deficient mice results from impaired adaptive proliferation of peroxisomes in response to the oxidative stress. In wild-type mice, loud sounds elicit adaptive peroxisomal proliferation.
item.dc:title: Hypervulnerability to Sound Exposure through Impaired Adaptive Proliferation of Peroxisomes
item.dc:creator: Sedigheh Delmaghani, Jean Defourny, Asadollah Aghaie, Maryline Beurg, Didier Dulon, Nicolas Thelen, Isabelle Perfettini, Tibor Zelles, Mate Aller, Anaïs Meyer, Alice Emptoz, Fabrice Giraudet, Michel Leibovici, Sylvie Dartevelle, Guillaume Soubigou, Marc Thiry, E. Sylvester Vizi, Saaid Safieddine, Jean-Pierre Hardelin, Paul Avan, Christine Petit

item.title: Vesicle-Mediated Steroid Hormone Secretion in
item.description: The release of the steroid hormone ecdysone in Drosophila is mediated through a vesicular trafficking mechanism regulated via calcium signaling, suggesting that steroid hormones may be actively released from cells, as opposed to simply diffusing across the membrane.
item.dc:title: Vesicle-Mediated Steroid Hormone Secretion in
item.dc:creator: Naoki Yamanaka, Guillermo Marqués, Michael B. O’Connor

item.title: 53BP1 and the LINC Complex Promote Microtubule-Dependent DSB Mobility and DNA Repair
item.description: Increased chromatin mobility at sites of double-stranded breaks is mediated by 53BP1, SUN1/2 in the nuclear envelope, and microtubule dynamics and contributes to aberrant DNA repair in cells with multiple DNA breaks.
item.dc:title: 53BP1 and the LINC Complex Promote Microtubule-Dependent DSB Mobility and DNA Repair
item.dc:creator: Francisca Lottersberger, Roos Anna Karssemeijer, Nadya Dimitrova, Titia de Lange

item.title: Fezf2 Orchestrates a Thymic Program of Self-Antigen Expression for Immune Tolerance
item.description: To promote immunological tolerance of one’s own proteins, the protein Fezf2 directly regulates transcription of tissue-restricted antigen genes in in the thymus, where it functions independently and via a distinct pathway from Aire, the transcriptional regulator widely thought to be primarily responsible for self-tolerance.
item.dc:title: Fezf2 Orchestrates a Thymic Program of Self-Antigen Expression for Immune Tolerance
item.dc:creator: Hiroyuki Takaba, Yasuyuki Morishita, Yoshihiko Tomofuji, Lynett Danks, Takeshi Nitta, Noriko Komatsu, Tatsuhiko Kodama, Hiroshi Takayanagi
